page.title: 12Making Cement
page.content: Chinnor Cement Works makes 6 varieties ofcement for building and making concrete. The work is hard but,with modern technology,less so than in the days.The cement is made from calcium carbonate (chalk) quarried from the Chiltern escarpment.It is converted into cement by a kilning process. It is distributed either in a dry, bagged form or bulk by a fleet of 11 flat-backed and 16 cylinder lorries; each carrying either 15 or 20 tonnes. The Cement Works is operative for 24 hours a day and is one of six works owned by Rugby Portland Cement plc., distributed throughout the central and eastern part of England. About 20 years ago extensive drilling trials were carried out at Chinnor in connection with the proposed Channel Tunnel,because of the similarity betweenthe chalk here and at Dover.
